message_1: A rectangular block of wood measures 10cm x 15cm x 20cm and has a density of 0.6 g/cm³. The block is placed in a container of water with a depth of 30cm. Calculate the buoyant force acting on the block and determine if it will float or sink in the water. (Assume the acceleration due to gravity is 9.8 m/s² and the density of water is 1 g/cm³.)
message_2:
First, we need to find the volume of the block. The volume of a rectangular block can be calculated using the formula:

Volume = length × width × height

In this case, the volume of the block is:

Volume = 10 cm × 15 cm × 20 cm = 3000 cm³

Next, we need to find the mass of the block. The mass can be calculated using the formula:

Mass = density × volume

In this case, the mass of the block is:

Mass = 0.6 g/cm³ × 3000 cm³ = 1800 g

Now, we need to find the weight of the block. The weight can be calculated using the formula:

Weight = mass × acceleration due to gravity

In this case, the weight of the block is:

Weight = 1800 g × 9.8 m/s² = 1800 g × 0.0098 N/g = 17.64 N

Now, we need to find the buoyant force acting on the block. The buoyant force can be calculated using the formula:

Buoyant force = density of water × volume of the block × acceleration due to gravity

In this case, the buoyant force is:

Buoyant force = 1 g/cm³ × 3000 cm³ × 9.8 m/s² = 1 g/cm³ × 3000 cm³ × 0.0098 N/g = 29.4 N

Now, we can compare the buoyant force and the weight of the block to determine if it will float or sink. If the buoyant force is greater than the weight, the block will float. If the buoyant force is less than the weight, the block will sink.

In this case, the buoyant force (29.4 N) is greater than the weight of the block (17.64 N), so the block will float in the water.
